com.vincestyling.asqliteplus.statement

Class CreateStatement

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.vincestyling.asqliteplus.statement.Statement
      • com.vincestyling.asqliteplus.statement.CreateStatement

  • public class CreateStatement
extends Statement
    A statement producer that use to producing INSERT command of SQL language. The completed SQL statement would be sent to SQLiteDatabase objects to execute.
    See Also:
    DBOverseer

    • Method Detail

      • orRollback

        public static CreateStatement orRollback(java.lang.CharSequence table)
        Producing an "INSERT OR ROLLBACK INTO ..." statement.

        ROLLBACK resolution algorithm aborts the current SQL statement when an applicable constraint violation occurs and rolls back the current transaction if within.

        If no transaction is active, this algorithm works the same as the ABORT algorithm.

        Checking the SQLite documentation for more details.

        Parameters:
        table - the name of the table to inserting.
        Returns:
        the created statement.
        See Also:
        SQLiteDatabase.CONFLICT_ROLLBACK

      • orReplace

        public static CreateStatement orReplace(java.lang.CharSequence table)
        Producing an "INSERT OR REPLACE INTO ..."(equivalent to "REPLACE INTO ...") statement.

        When an UNIQUE or PRIMARY KEY constraint violation occurs, the REPLACE algorithm silently deletes pre-existing rows that are causing the constraint violation prior to inserting the current row.

        Checking the SQLite documentation for more details.

        Note: For compatibility with MySQL, SQLite allows us use the single keyword REPLACE as an alias for "INSERT OR REPLACE". So if you're looking for a method which building a statement like "REPLACE INTO ...", then this would be equivalent.

        Parameters:
        table - the name of the table to inserting.
        Returns:
        the created statement.
        See Also:
        SQLiteDatabase.CONFLICT_REPLACE, SQLiteDatabase.replace(String, String, android.content.ContentValues)

      • orIgnore

        public static CreateStatement orIgnore(java.lang.CharSequence table)
        Producing an "INSERT OR IGNORE INTO ..." statement.

        When an applicable constraint violation occurs, the IGNORE resolution algorithm skips the one row that contains the constraint violation and continues processing subsequent rows of the SQL statement as if nothing went wrong.

        Checking the SQLite documentation for more details.

        Parameters:
        table - the name of the table to inserting.
        Returns:
        the created statement.
        See Also:
        SQLiteDatabase.CONFLICT_IGNORE

      • orAbort

        public static CreateStatement orAbort(java.lang.CharSequence table)
        Producing an "INSERT OR ABORT INTO ..." statement.

        When an applicable constraint violation occurs, the ABORT resolution algorithm aborts the current SQL statement with an SQLITE_CONSTRAINT error and backs out any changes made by the current SQL statement, but changes caused by prior SQL statements within the same transaction are preserved and the transaction remains active.

        This is the default behavior and the behavior specified by the SQL standard. That means "INSERT OR ABORT INTO ..." equivalent to "INSERT INTO ...".

        Checking the SQLite documentation for more details.

        Parameters:
        table - the name of the table to inserting.
        Returns:
        the created statement.
        See Also:
        SQLiteDatabase.CONFLICT_ABORT

      • orFail

        public static CreateStatement orFail(java.lang.CharSequence table)
        Producing an "INSERT OR FAIL INTO ..." statement.

        When an applicable constraint violation occurs, the FAIL resolution algorithm aborts the current SQL statement with an SQLITE_CONSTRAINT error. But the FAIL resolution does not back out prior changes of the SQL statement that failed nor does it end the transaction.

        Parameters:
        table - the name of the table to inserting.
        Returns:
        the created statement.
        See Also:
        SQLiteDatabase.CONFLICT_FAIL

      • produce

        protected static CreateStatement produce(java.lang.CharSequence table,
                      java.lang.CharSequence clause)
        Producing an INSERT statement with a clause. This method should be work with orXXX() which in this Statement, don't call it directly.
        Parameters:
        table - the name of the table to inserting.
        Returns:
        the created statement.

      • produce

        public static CreateStatement produce(java.lang.CharSequence table)
        Producing an "INSERT INTO ..." statement without clause.
        Parameters:
        table - the name of the table to inserting.
        Returns:
        the created statement.

      • entry

        public CreateStatement entry(Statement stmt)
        Using a SELECT statement instead of a VALUES clause. A new entry is inserted into the table for each row of data returned by executing the SELECT statement.

        A correct form of the produced SQL would like "insert into first_tbl_name(column-1, column-2) (select column-1, column-2 from second_tbl_name)".

        Notice: The columns(Object...) method which used to specifying table columns must have already have been called before enable this clause.

        Interesting to know more details about "INSERT with SELECT"? check the SQLite documentation's describe about "The second form of the INSERT statement".

        Parameters:
        stmt - the subquery statement.
        Returns:
        this statement.

      • columns

        public CreateStatement columns(java.lang.Object... columns)
        Concatenates all the given column names. Used for cooperating with entry(Statement) method.
        Parameters:
        columns - the column names.
        Returns:
        this statement.

      • put

        public CreateStatement put(java.lang.CharSequence column,
                  java.lang.Object value)
        Put a single field pair to constructing a conventional format's INSERT statement.
        Parameters:
        column - column name.
        value - column value, will auto quoting if instance of CharSequence.
        Returns:
        this statement.
